sub_topic: Calculation of thermodynamic properties of molecules and reactions.
message_1: What is the change in entropy (ΔS) when 1 mole of hydrogen gas (H2) reacts with 1 mole of chlorine gas (Cl2) to form 2 moles of hydrogen chloride gas (2HCl) at a temperature of 298 K and a pressure of 1 atm?
message_2:
To calculate the change in entropy (ΔS) for the reaction, we need to find the difference between the entropy of the products and the entropy of the reactants. We can use the standard molar entropies (S°) for each substance at 298 K and 1 atm, which can be found in standard thermodynamic tables.

Standard molar entropies (S°) at 298 K and 1 atm:
H2(g) = 130.68 J/mol·K
Cl2(g) = 223.07 J/mol·K
HCl(g) = 186.90 J/mol·K

The balanced chemical equation for the reaction is:
H2(g) + Cl2(g) → 2HCl(g)

Now, we can calculate the change in entropy (ΔS) using the following equation:
ΔS = ΣS°(products) - ΣS°(reactants)

ΔS = [2 * S°(HCl)] - [S°(H2) + S°(Cl2)]

ΔS = [2 * 186.90 J/mol·K] - [130.68 J/mol·K + 223.07 J/mol·K]

ΔS = [373.80 J/mol·K] - [353.75 J/mol·K]

ΔS = 20.05 J/mol·K

The change in entropy (ΔS) for the reaction is 20.05 J/mol·K.
